fields.description:
I created the bug for 3.0.5 but actually it is about 3.0.6, I just didn't find tag 3.0.6

After minimizing SourceTree I can't open its window again. When I press a button in taskbar I hear a sound like it has some modal window that interrupts to set the focus.

It happened right after I updated SourceTree to 3.0.6, there was no such problem before.
fields.summary: Can't show SourceTree after minimize

fields.description:
**Steps below illustrate the problem for a private github repo but the problem exists also for VSTS. I have not tested other providers.

 

On a clean, freshly installed Windows 10 machine:
 # Install SourceTree 3.0.5-beta-2178 (tried with the non enterprise edition) or SourceTree 2.6.10
 # Install git for Windows 2.19.1 from [https://git-scm.com/] 
 # Configure SourceTree to use "system git" as opposed to "embedded git"
 # Attempt to clone a *private* GitHub repo of your choice

 

*ACTUAL BEHAVIOR*: SourceTree spins forever trying to determine the type of repo - No UI is presented to enter username / password
 *EXPECTED BEHAVIOR*: Modal dialog is presented (perhaps by credential manager?) allowing user to enter GitHub credentials.

 

Earlier versions of git for windows (aka 2.19.0 and below) work well. It is only a problem with git for windows 2.19.1

 

*COMPARE* - With embedded git provided by SourceTree:
 * With git 2.19.1 installed, configure SourceTree to use "embedded git" instead of "system git"
 * Close and restart SourceTree
 * Try to clone the same repo as in step 4 above
 * OBSERVE: Dialog pops up asking for credentials and clone continues when valid credentials are entered.

*COMPARE* - With git command line:
 * Open a cmd.exe prompt
 * Run git --version to verify "System git" version 2.19.1 is being used
 * git clone <repo from step 4>
 * OBSERVE: {color:#172b4d}Dialog pops up asking for credentials and clone continues when valid credentials are entered{color}.
fields.summary: SourceTree can no longer authenticate to any repo after upgrade to git for Windows 2.19.1

fields.description:
git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false --no-optional-locks -c credential.helper= -c credential.helper="C:/Users/tpayne/AppData/Local/ATLASS~1/SOURCE~1/GIT_EX~1/GIT-CR~1.EXE" push -v origin feature/DE1832_US3561_Merge:feature/DE1832_US3561_Merge
remote: You are not allowed to upload code.
fatal: unable to access 'https://oauth2:bMYMGLLvU6cpFe9cjGyH@git.dataservices.htec.co.uk/NXG/Jupiter.Europa.git/': The requested URL returned error: 403

Pushing to https://oauth2:bMYMGLLvU6cpFe9cjGyH@git.dataservices.htec.co.uk/NXG/Jupiter.Europa.git
Completed with errors, see above.
fields.summary: Keep getting a recurring access error when trying to push

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
 # Right-click your top stash and delete it
 # Before the delete is finished (it is extremely slow), right-click stash number 2 and delete that too.
 # You will get a confirmation box that mentions the name of stash number 2.

Result: top stash, and stash number 3 are deleted.

Expected: top stash and stash number 2 are deleted.

I understand that it is because the index is changed etc, but since the confirmation dialogue mentions the stash by name, the stash with that name should be deleted.
fields.summary: Sourcetree deletes the wrong stash

fields.summary: Cannot Checkout in sourcetree

fields.description: If the user decides to delete a remote branch, all local branches that are tracking this one should be also deleted. It can be an optional function like a checkbox to let the user decides to delete local branches or not.
fields.summary: Delete remote brarch also delete local branches that are tracking the deleting branch

fields.description:
When you double-click on a commit to check it out, when the commit is the head of a branch on a remote server, the tool always prompts to Check New Branch, with a list of remote branches, and letting you name the local branch.

However, in a situation such as working on master, making 3-4 local commits and then finding that an item is broken, it is a normal test to want to know if it started broken or if your edits broke it.  So check out origin/master.  But you are already on master.

In this case, you generally want detached head (you are checking out a specific commit to compare results), but the SourceTree UI gives no way to do this.

The workaround is to drop to the command line and do:

git checkout PASTECOMMITSHAHERE
fields.summary: Clicking on branch from origin attempts forces into create branch

fields.description:
Start SourceTree for Windows. It starts successfully.

Minimize SourceTree using the minimize button on the upper right. It minimizes successfully.

Click SourceTree on the menu bar. It doesn't restore the window, and an error sound happens. FAIL.

I have to close SourceTree and restart the app to get the window back.
fields.summary: Minimize SourceTree on Windows 7, then can't restore.

fields.description:
When minimized, the application window can not be restored by clicking on task bar button.

As a workaround, I was able to use ALT+SPACE and select "Restore" from the context menu.

 

This is reproducible also on other Windows 10 machine.
fields.summary: Can not restore minimized window

fields.description:
Once minimized the application window can not be restores by clicking on task bar button.

As a work around, I can press ALT + SPACE and select "Restore" from displayed menu.

 

The issue was reproduced also on other win 10 computer.
fields.summary: Can not restore minimized window

fields.description:
After minimizing Sourcetree using the minimize button in the window title bar, it is hardly possible to restore the window again. Maybe one out of ten trials is successful, i.e. the Sourcetree window is restored. In all other instance you hear only the Windows notification sound.

This is independent of the window state (regular/maximized).

When Sourcetree is minimized via the application icon in the task bar (single click while active), another click on the icon will restore the window without problems.
fields.summary: Window does not get restored after minimization

fields.description:
When viewing the changes in local and remote commits via the tree view a git-receive-pack.exe process begins. This process appears to be orphaned and never ends even after closing Sourcetree. Viewing numerous commits obviously continues to produce more of these processes.

This is easy to reproduce just by clicking on various commits in the tree view and watching the list of process grow via the task manager. Observe that after closing sourcetree these processes persist.
fields.summary: Orphaned git-receive-pack.exe processes

fields.description:
On the Log/History tab, change the width of the pane with the log text in it.

Then press F5 to refresh.

The pane reverts back to its default width.

 

If you use line breaks in commit messages, which is quite common, the default width can often break your lines prematurely, making reading logs difficult. The application should remember the splitter position.
fields.summary: Log/History pane does not remember its width

fields.description:
How to disable option "Help improve sourcetree by sending data about your usage" after installing SourcetreeEnterpriseSetup_2.6.10.msi by default.

+What I tried?+

Tried to disable option in C:\Users\XXXX\AppData\Local\Atlassian\SourceTree.exe_Url_yjhzxxhcu2ommegrdorjf3q1oqllqxiq\2.6.10.0\user.config

<setting name="AnalyticsDisplayOptIn" serializeAs="String">
 <value>False</value>
 </setting>

But if I go for new installation this folder won't available C:\Users\XXXX\AppData\Local\Atlassian\SourceTree.exe_Url_yjhzxxhcu2ommegrdorjf3q1oqllqxiq

 

Is it immediately sending the information to Atlassian by enabling the option and click next or sending the info after completing the initial setup
fields.summary: How to disable option "Help improve sourcetree by sending data about your usage"

fields.description: Every time I open SourceTree I faced with popup messages about GIT LFS. Could you please remove it? Thank you :)
fields.summary: GIT LFS messages

fields.description:
The local repository list window is very erratic and misbehaves.  I've had all of the following experiences:
 # When attempting to rename repositories in the list:
 ## Rename a repository and save it.
 ## Click on the next repository and that repository is highlighted but the previously edited repository remains highlighted.
 ## This continued to be true for all listed repositories; i.e., by the time I had clicked the fourth entry to rename it, all of the prior three remain highlighted.
 ## Only when I hit Esc did it unhighlight any of them.
 # After making a commit to multiple different repositories, the repository list continues to display the "refresh" icon
 ## After closing the app and restarting it, the refresh icons initially displayed and then went away as I expected they should originally.
fields.summary: Local repository list window is very bugging and erratic

fields.description:
When going to "Remote", it initially displayed my account and then (after a while) the list of repositories from my organization.  Then, after they had populated, I attempted to scroll the list and the program aborted.  (NOTE: It came up with a bugsplat dialog which I entered info and submitted.)

Since then, whenever I start SourceTree and go to "Remotes", it does not display my account nor does it display any repositories, nor does it make an attempt to populate the list.  (NOTE: I have tried deleting the ~\AppData\Local\Atlassian folder and then going through the setup again but the same behavior resulted, though it did not bugsplat since that first time.)

However, I can successfully clone repositories using the URL supplied in Bitbucket so there is at least a workaround.  Maybe a better option given how long it takes to populate the list of repositories!
fields.summary: Remote repositories do not list

fields.description:
Until recent update my workflow was to commit and push at the same time. Now I can't do that because Sourcetree keeps forgetting the branch I am pushing to. It's so annoying.

It's random. Sometimes the branch is filled in like it should other times not. This worked perfectly until this update.

!image-2018-09-28-17-38-49-443.png!
fields.summary: Broken update 3.0.3
Stash with "keep all uncommitted changes"

fields.description: Standalone on Windows 10.
fields.summary: Commit with Push fails after 3.03 Upgrade

fields.description:
Sometimes (very often) when ready to commit, the remote branch is blank even if it exist in the origin (see screenshoot).

After a few swap between branch or project, it will detect the branch again.
fields.summary: Remote branch blank
when I use sourceTree version more than 2.0， I can‘t  choose which folder be installed

fields.description: Source Tree v2.6.10.0 for windows 10 always asking for password & it's annoying me.
fields.summary: Source Tree v2.6.10.0

fields.description:
Sourcetree for the past few months will occasionally pop up a dialog asking me to log in to Bitbucket. If I don't enter anything, it will continue to pop up more and more dialogs. On earlier versions of SourceTree I've seen these coincide with fetch events in the Process Viewer / Log. I guess when it goes to fetch from Bitbucket every 10 minutes, it opens a dialog for each of my local repos.

I've been testing the SourceTree 3.0.0 beta branch for a week or two now hoping that this was fixed but I came to my computer this evening (which I last logged into this morning) to find hundreds of Bitbucket credential dialogs open (see screenshot; each of those windows has ~20 behind it in the same spot). These were also slowing my computer to a crawl so logging in took minutes instead of seconds.

 The worst part of all of this is that even if I'm here and enter my log in information, it doesn't accept it. Manual remote operations will fail and I end up having to go into the terminal to successfully complete the operation. The only way I've been able to get it to work is to go into the remotes section and resync my oauth token for Bitbucket. However, this doesn't last more than a few days at best.

I never have this issue with Github and I really don't understand why the two Atlassian products are so broken with one another. I have several staff as well and I've seen this on every one of their computers.
fields.summary: Bitbucket never accepts credentials and creates excessive login dialogs
Sourcetree full window mode doesnt work on Win 10

fields.description:
In older versions of SourceTree (up to 1.7, I believe), I could easily have an overview of all the projects and repositories I was working on, using the left-hand side workspace tree view.

I am badly missing it:

!image-2017-09-12-06-11-36-817.png!
fields.summary: Bring back the left-hand side worspace tree view

fields.description: SourceTree apparently does not let us know when our GIT Auth Token expires. Kept asking me to log in again and again without letting me know that the token is expired. Went into Authentication setting in SourceTree and saw that the Token did not work and then Refreshed OAuth Token. After that Logged in into the dialog box that was popping up which made it work. Need better indication on expired tokens
fields.summary: No Indication On Expired Git OAuth Token

Sometimes the log select option is disabled. After restart it works.

!image-2018-04-09-10-26-02-846.png!
fields.summary: log selected

fields.description: Windows 7 x64 @ 1920x1080
fields.summary: Edit Custom Actions dialog buttons are cropped

fields.description:
* This happens currently in two places:

- In the Tag Details dialog (right click on Tag, select Details ... option), the commit message is rendered as dialog text, not as a scrollable text pane.
As a result, if the message of the commit that the tag refers to is long enough, the dialog window will stretch past the bottom of the screen, extending to such a point that the OK control is no longer visible or accessible with the mouse.

- If you try to reset a branch to a certain commit which has a long commit message, the reset branch dialog tries to fit the whole commit message into a single line which makes the dialog exceedingly wide. If a commit message is long enough the reset type picker and the ok and cancel buttons are outside the screen and cannot be changed.
fields.summary: long commit message hides dialog buttons
Can not activate SourceTree license due to JavaScript load error!?

fields.description: Bitbutcket Remote Repositories will show after fresh install of Sourcetree app on Windows 10, but stop showing after a day or so. Uninstalled and removed all Souretree related files and removed credentials in Windows Credential Manager. Re-installed and remote repos were visible then stopped showing after a while. Created groups with member permissions set to everyone can create repos, and everyone with admin privileges.
fields.summary: Remote Repositories for Bitbucket server not showing on SourceTree
Sourcetree Setup for Windows login fail

fields.description:
Similar to SRCTREEWIN-6320 , but with the specific difference that the .gitattributes file is in a subdirectory.  

 

Steps to reproduce:
 # Clone [https://github.com/cowlinator/lfstest-individual-files] 
 # `cd` into the repository and rename big-file1.bin to folder\bigfile1.file (note the directory and extension change) by running the command `cp big-file1.bin folder/big-file1.file`
 # Add folder/big-file1.file in SourceTree to the next commit. On add I get this error message:

!lfs_error.png|thumbnail!

 

Expected behavior:

The file is added without the lfs error message

Problem:

The file is already tracked by GitLFS but SourceTree does not recognize the 2nd .gitattributes at `folder\.gitattributes`.  To prove that it is tracked, manually add the file with `git add folder/big-file1.file` and then run `git lfs ls-files`.  You will see that it is already tracked by lfs, but SourceTree is incorrectly giving an error stating that it is not.
fields.summary: Incorrect warning when adding LFS tracked file in a subfolder (with subfolder .gitattributes)
Source can not install Windows 10 Pro 64 bit

fields.description:
SourceTree returns the following error while trying refresh Bitbucket's OAuth token by clicking on "Refresh OAuth Token" button

 !image-2018-09-18-09-19-02-420.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Steps to reproduce
# Navigate to *Tools>Options*
# Click "Authentication" tab
# Click *Add* to add new account
# Select the following options
#* *Bitbucket* as the Hosting Service 
#* *HTTPS* as Preferred Protocol
#* *OAuth* as the Authentication
# Click "Refresh OAuth Token"

h3. Workaround
Use *Basic* Authentication
fields.summary: Unable to Refresh OAuth Token

fields.description:
Try to associate a gitlab account and it will crash.

Go to accounts, click add new account, choose gitlab. Use either http or ssh , then choose to refresh personal access token, type in your username and password and source tree will crash, every time. Tried multiple times and it crashes 100%. attached log generated on crash. This log was generated using SSH as my method.
fields.summary: Crashed on logging in to Gitlab

How can I browse the projects I am maintainer and developer of? Many are made by someone else and I am simply a dev.
 
Not sure if there was something on the server side I was supposed to set to make them appear

fields.description:
When I open SourceTree, I get a white and black rectangle with no visible features. I can still use the right-click menu (if I have any tabs open), but I get no visual feedback.

I have tried wiping my preferences (using [these instructions|https://confluence.atlassian.com/sourcetreekb/how-to-wipe-sourcetree-preferences-412484640.html?_ga=2.85648345.1183101431.1536786815-1628839743.1523638198]) and reinstalling, to no avail.

The attached screenshot is the SourceTree error in front of my browser window.
fields.summary: SourceTree opens as a featureless black and white window

fields.description:
After updating to the newest Sourcetree (2.6.10), when I went to open my existing Github repositories, it requested my Github credentials.  I entered them correctly and then Sourcetree again prompted me for my Github credentials.  This continued in an infinite loop until I gave up on attempting to connect to my Github account.

I was able to stop this from happening by uninstalling Sourcetree, deleting my Atlassian folder in AppData/Local, reinstalling Sourcetree, and then adding my Github account back in.

I tried other various solutions from within Sourcetree like removing my Github account and adding it back in, but it would not work until I deleted the Atlassian folder.  I did not try just deleting the Atlassian folder (without reinstallation), but I have a hunch that would work.

I had the same thing happen on my laptop, desktop, and Surface Pro 4, I teach game development and 3 other students in my class (so far) have had the same issue.  Most of the students did not have an older version of Sourcetree, so I assume that is why they didn't encounter the issue.

This same issue has actually been re-occuring since the initial release of Sourcetree 2.0.  Each time I upgrade Sourcetree I have this same problem and I have been able to work around it the same way for about 3 years.  It would be nice for this issue to actually get fixed.

Feel free to follow up with any questions.
fields.summary: Github Login "loop" after upgrade to new SourceTree

fields.description:
We have installed Sourcetree Enterprise 2.6.10. When we are browsing for repositories to clone on the remote environment ( ours is a on-premise Bitbucket server) we do not get all our repositories. It seems like that only the top 30-35 alphabetically ordered repositories in a Bitbucket project environment are found.

We suspect that the results from query to bitbucket are abbreviated. Is this a setting or configuration issue?

Our Users report that previous non Enterprise Sourcetree did and do find all repositories.
fields.summary: Enterprise Sourcetree does not get all repositories from on premise Bitbucket Server

fields.description:
In the installation process.
 * Manually type "Root URL"
 * Bitbucket , Bitbucket server
 * 

 These things are so confusing. I need to googling and try many times to pass it.
fields.summary: Very hard to install SourceTree.

fields.description: When you have allot of merge conflicts, and already resolved them, the textbox does not have a set height, so you cant see the commit button at the bottom, and is unable to commit.
fields.summary: Merge conflicts cant Scroll to commit code

fields.description: As a user, the handy feature to use command prompt or shell is really useful. However, if there is an option to allow user to provide the link to cmd.exe or git bash or powershell, it will be really helpful for user. In some projects which requires commands from both shell and cmd prompt, if there is a third option for powershell, it will be really helpful.
fields.summary: Allow user to use powershell option instead of command prompt

fields.description: I would like to have an option to search/filter the log/history window by the commit message/description. Something like an inplace textbox when you hit strg+f
fields.summary: Search in Log/History by commit message/description

fields.description: I would like to have an option to search/filter the log/history window by the commit message/description. Something like an inplace textbox when you hit strg+f
fields.summary: Search in Log/History by commit message/description

fields.description:
We have custom cherry-pick defined in Custom Actions (we need to review changes before committing them) which also creates .git/MERGE_MSG file, but the prepared commit message is not reflected in Sourcetree (commit message textarea in Sourcetree is empty). I believe ST doesn't check if this file was created or not after performing Custom Action.

Could ST check for that file after every Custom Action is performed and if it exists, prefill ST's commit message textarea with content of that file?

Thanks.
fields.summary: ST doesn't respect .git/MERGE_MSG after Custom Action

fields.description:
# In the log window, select two commit that are not nearby. 
 # In right click menu, select create patch.
 # Check the created patch file. It doesn't contain the actual difference between the two commits. Instead it contains only the latest commit.
fields.summary: Can't create correct patch between two commits

fields.description:
There is a workaround for stashing only selected files, but it is awkward:
[https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Sourcetree-questions/Stashing-selected-files/qaq-p/137139]

I frequently find myself wanting to commit portions of what I'm working on to a different branch. Being able to divide my uncommitted changes into different stashes so I can apply them to the desired branches would be very helpful. Example: I'm in the middle of working some one big feature when a simple bug is reported. I fix the bug in the development environment, test, and want to commit that one change to the released branch and push to staging/production.

Thank you for an awesome product.
fields.summary: Support stashing selected files only

fields.description: I can log into Atlassian.  I logged in to create this ticket, but when I try to download Source Tree, I click that I agree, it asks if I want to log in using Atlassian, then I get an error trying to log in saying something went wrong.  I can reset my password, and I still get the same error, but I can log into Atlassian with the same email and password.
fields.summary: I cannot download source  tree

fields.description:
Open a repository located in the disk root directory.

Click <Actions> -> <Open In Terminal> and you will see, that terminal will not be opened.

 

We usually mount a special disk for our internal purposes using a <subst ...> command. It's a pretty common use case, so we consider that the bug should be fixed.
fields.summary: Cannot open a terminal via GUI for a repository located in a disk root folder

fields.description:
I have Windows 10 Pro version 1809 build 17754.1 and both the application runtime or the installer no longer recognizes that I have a valid .NET version installed - the error I get is "The application requires one of the following versions of the .NET Framework - .NET Framework, Version=v4.7.1

However, as I said, I have 4.7.2 installed which I verified
fields.summary: SourcTree application and SourceTree installer does not recognize .NET 4.7.2

fields.description:
Hi,

I am using an old version of SourceTree. I just downloaded the newest version and logged in using my Bitbucket credentials. Then it displays "OK". And then nothing happens. Also clicking the Next button does not do anything. After minutes of waiting i closed the installer and tried again, but with no other result. I cannot make it working on Win7 Professional.

I forced closed it and thus got the error reporting wizard and reported it.
fields.summary: Installer does not finish

fields.description:
Create several not empty commits.

Create an empty commit.

If you select a not empty commit, you will see the changes in the view (1_new.PNG).

Now if you select the empty commit, the view will not be changed. It still contains information about files from the previous commit (2_new.PNG).
fields.summary: An empty commit contains a view with changes from another commit

fields.description: Unable to configure GitLab as a hosted account.  When trying to "Refresh Personal Access Token" unable to authenticate.  This fails on GitLab.com for any two-factored accounts, and GitLab CE and EE instances with SAML authentication.  There needs to be a field to manually enter a personal access token.
fields.summary: Can't add GitLab hosting account

fields.description: Would you please add a theme with dark colors? Working with the text based interface with a white background is not easy. A theme with dark colors, would make the interface much easier on the eyes.
fields.summary: Dark colored theme

fields.description:
While annotate and log history are very useful, neither give users a way to inspect the diff on a file from one revision to another. This can be implemented with a master detail view where the master view is two lists containing the revisions where a file was changed. The detail view displays the diff between the selected revisions.

The requested feature resembles what tortoisehg provides as "Compare file revisions" or the "File log viewer" dialog.
fields.summary: Users want to compare any revision of a files with any other revision in the history

fields.description:
Browsing files and folders on a commit gives a user the ability to compare the working copy with a point in history without the need of having a second clone of the repository. The requested functionality resembles what the "manifest window" in tortoisehg allows users to do. In tortoisehg a user can "browse at revision" in the revision context menu.

This issue reopens SRCTREEWIN-341 which had several upvotes but was probably closed in error.
fields.summary: Users want to browse files and folders in the repositories history without checkout of that commit

fields.description: When my remote repository alias has just 2 characters, then Sourcetree somehow duplicates names of some local branches in the list of local branches. It's the same branch but shown twice. See attached screenshot.
fields.summary: When remote alias is just 2 characters, there is duplication of local branch names

fields.description:
After using SourceTree for multiple hours, when selecting a single commit, the commit window looks like this:

??Displaying all changes between df1a55194519084fadd437c1bc1a1cc06fba5d85 and 082b71fcffa85648a215764d56f8282cc34c0965??

But visually, only a single commit is selected.  ctrl-selecting multiple commits doesn't even visually work at this point, and I am unable to "reset" the UI except by restarting the app.

Unfortunately, I'm unaware of any particular steps that can be taken to reproduce this issue, but it consistently happens on my PC.  

Note:  I'm aware of one thing I'm certain is *not* involved in reproducing this issue, which is ctrl-selecting multiple commits.  This is not a feature I normally use, and in fact only became aware it existed because of this bug.

I've discovered a workaround, which is switching to another repository and back.
fields.summary: Windows UI eventually refuses to show a single commit

fields.description:
Replication steps:
 # Prepare a git repo with some large files.
 # Stage all the files at once
 # Wonder if you clicked the "Stage selected" or "Stage All" button and click them again
 # Wait a bit, then get error about git process already in use and locked

Suggested solution:
 # After clicking stage or stage all, show a progress bar and grey out the stage all and stage selected buttons, just like what happens when commit is clicked
 # When the staging is completed, remove the progress bar.
fields.summary: SourceTree hangs after clicking Stage Selected or Stage All on large files

fields.description:
Currently whenever you view a merge commit you'll see a combined list of changed files to all parents which affects usability a lot since normally there would be lots of files with 'no changes detected'.
When selecting a file there is an option to select which parent to show the diff to but that should be moved to view options so it only shows files different to selected parent.
fields.summary: Apply parent filter to file list in merge commits
Allow close last page with opened repository.

fields.description:
When you open the About dialog, it gets its own icon in the taskbar. But the About dialog is modal, so it really shouldn't do this.

With the about dialog open, if you Alt+Tab, it will switch focus to the main window, but since there's a modal open, the focus switches back to the About dialog.

The same thing happens with the Options dialog too.

 

It's a _really, really_ easy fix. Just set {{ShowInTaskbar}} to false on the {{AboutWindow}} class. :D
fields.summary: About dialog gets an icon in the taskbar

fields.description:
When I add a Bitbucket Server hosting account to SourceTree, the initial login check succeeds. However, on the actual Remote Repositories screen, one of two things will happen:
 # It lists my personal repositories and one other repo which is public, but none of the other repositories to which I have access.
 # Authentication fails with the following message:

{noformat}
Unable to read repositories for the user from the remote host
Failed to list repositories for the user [gordon.tyler]: You do not have permission to access the URL 'https://our.git.server.com/rest/api/1.0/users/gordon.tyler/repos?limit=30&start=0' please check the user credentials associated with this account. The request returned with status code 'Unauthorized'. You are not permitted to access this resource.{noformat}
When I click the Refresh link, it will randomly toggle between these two states.

I am entering the correct username and password. My user has system admin permissions in Bitbucket Server. I can clone repos via https using the same credentials or via ssh using the access key I have added to my Bitbucket Server account.

I found the following in the Bitbucket Server logs at the time that I attempted this:

fields.summary: Bitbucket Server remote account does not work reliably

fields.description: Every time I open Sourcetree I get a notification saying "A new version fo Git-LFS is available", despite having gone through Options > Git > Update Embedded.
fields.summary: "A new version fo Git-LFS is available" Notification

fields.description:
While resolving a merge conflict, I removed the '#Conflicts' portion of the commit message in the  Commit Message window. After entering text, I selected a file and clicked the 'Stage Selected' button. However, the commit message was reverted to the '#Conflicts' one.

This issue was thought to be fixed in 2.6 (SRCTREEWIN-8620) and I did not notice the issue until upgrading (yesterday) to 2.6.10 from an earlier 2.6 version.
fields.summary: Commit message cleared when I stage changed files - Regressed
Not able to push to repository

fields.description:
Sourcetree has issues with repositories that have a redirected working directory using core.workdir. It seems for certain checks and actions Sourcetree is using the original working directory path instead of core.workdir.
 # Create a new repository at "A:/repo/".
 # Create a new file "test.txt", stage and commit it.
 # Add "core.workdir=B:/workdir" to the git config. Sourcetree will report "test.txt" as deleted (which is expected behavior).
 # Discard the change, change the file content and commit. This will work as expected as well.
 # Now delete the file in the original working dir, "A:/repo/test.txt".
 # Change its content again and try to stage the change via "Stage selected" or the file context menu. The file will be deleted in the working directory and staged as deleted instead of changed.
 # Discard the deleted file. This will restore the file in the working dir, though the changes are gone.
 # Create a new file in "B:/workdir/new.txt" with the content "Foo".
 # Sourcetree will detect a new file, though is unable to display its content and will throw a "fatal: pathspec 'new.txt' did not match any files" error, when trying to stage it. Log output show Sourctree runs git rm, instead of git add.
 # Now create a file in "A:/repo/new.txt" with the content "Bar". Sourcetree still shows a new file, though with the content "Bar". Adding/staging it will now work. After staging it, Sourcetree will display its correct content "Foo".

All actions above are working as expected, when using a terminal and git directly.
fields.summary: core.worktree is not working properly for all actions

fields.description: Would you please add a theme with dark colors? Working with the text based interface with a white background is not easy. A theme with dark colors, would make the interface much easier on the eyes.
fields.summary: Dark colored theme
SourceTree keeps advising on update to Git-LFS though the later version is already installed

fields.description: Whenever I click on the Check for an Update or on the Notification Flag in the SourceTree's Window Bar, the User's .gitconfig [http] proxy is reset to google !?!
fields.summary: Checking for an update of SourceTree or clicking on the Notification Flag resets the computer's .gitconfig http proxy setting

fields.description:
#1 When pushing changes to my remote branch from command line sourcetree does not update/redraw the commit window to reflect the changes. Sometime you can simply click on a different branch so force souretree to update but sometimes it just wont update. In this case the only option is to restart sourcetree and this is were I've found another related bug.

#2 When sourcetree starts and the commit view is set to only show current branch, it will still show all branches. To only see my current branch I have to select 'current branch' from the interface although it's already selected.
fields.summary: Commit view does not update properly

fields.description:
There was an argument injection vulnerability in Sourcetree for Windows from version 0.5.1.0 before version 3.0.0  via Git subrepositories in Mercurial repositories. An attacker with permission to commit to a Mercurial repository linked in Sourcetree for Windows is able to exploit this issue to gain code execution on the system.


 

For additional details, see the [full advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/v00SOQ]
fields.summary: Remote Code Execution in Sourcetree for Windows, via Mercurial repo with Git subrepo - CVE-2018-13397

fields.description:
In the Force Push warning, it indicates that "one or more branch is selected for a force push".  It's very rare that I would ever force push more than one branch at once - in fact I can't remember ever doing it.  It would actually be beneficial to have a count of branches that are about to be force pushed. 

Telling me that 1 branch (or whatever I expect it to be) will be affected gives me confidence in what I'm about to do.  Telling me one or more makes me doubt what I'm about to do.
fields.summary: In the "Force Push" warning modal dialog, indicate the number of affected branches

fields.description: In Log / History window commits list text not visible (screenshot [here|https://ibb.co/jzM8hp]). Any way to change the background color (or font color)?
fields.summary: Work with Windows dark theme - window background color
No cursor

fields.description:
I use dark Gmail, dark IntelliJ IDEA, dark browser, everything is dark except SourceTree.

The white user interface kills my eyes. Can we have an option for a dark theme?
fields.summary: Implement a dark theme/skin

fields.description:
push gives the following messages, however Bitbucket does not show the updates.

git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false push -v --tags --set-upstream origin master:master
Branch 'master' set up to track remote branch 'master' from 'origin'.
Pushing to https://bakhrut:<mypassword>@bitbucket.org/bakhrut/sfcode.git
To https://bitbucket.org/bakhrut/sfcode.git
 = [up to date] master -> master
updating local tracking ref 'refs/remotes/origin/master'
Everything up-to-date

 


Completed successfully.
fields.summary: unable to push from sourcetree to bitbucket

fields.description:
Sorry if this is a duplicate, there are so many issues opened around the SSH auth that I couldn't easily find one that looked the same. 

I frequently leave SourceTree open on my computer overnight at the office. When I return in the morning and attempt to make connections to my repo, I get the SSH Auth Failed message, which is only resolvable by restarting SourceTree. Why would this happen? I'm using the OpenSSH agent, and it's running and has my key, so I'm not sure what I'm missing.

!image-2018-08-22-10-33-21-580.png!
fields.summary: SSH Auth Fails after leaving SourceTree open over night

fields.description:
Keeps prompting me for authentication and login. Even though my details are correct. 

Afterwards the dialog closes with no errors and then like prompts again for authentication.

I even did the refresh OAuth Token. But it still not working...
fields.summary: Authentications Error

fields.description:
I have a repository where the tip is revision 21.
I makes some works and create a commit (unpushed to my own central server) with revision 22 and another (always unpushed commit) with release 23.
Then I want to fold patches 22 and 23: selected revsion 21,22 and 23 and go to "Create Patch" command (that tell me that create a patch that "displaying all changes between 21 and 23").
After that I save this new FoldedPatches and strip 21 and 22 from local repository. Then I want to apply the folded patch, but sourcetree cannot apply (and TortoiseHg too).

I have misunderstanding the "Create Patch" command or is a bug?

Thanks in advance.
fields.summary: Create a new patch from 2 unpushed commits, create a wrong file

fields.description:
I have already seen some tickets that mention this same issue, but I cannot find a resolution: on GUI side is impossible to distinguish between a commit that was pushed to central server and a commit that isn't pushed to central server.

In my scenario, I have my own server where the source are located and not use an bitbucket\github repository.

Thanks in advance.
fields.summary: Cannot distinguish on GUI from unpushed commits and pushed commits
Clone error

fields.description: "Log / History" bottom tab - List of files. Non-English chars in filenames are unreadable and replaced with wrong <?> chars instead. Please note: Windows filenames are not in UTF8 as SourceTree expects, they are in national encodings.
fields.summary: Unreadable filenames if not in English
Installation: failure to validate account

fields.description:
While running SourceTree, approximately every 20 minutes, I get a dialog prompting me to login. 

I ignore it / dismiss it.

Another one pops up.

I ignore it / dismiss it.

Everything continues to work fine and all background operations seem to successfully complete. 

I am able to pull/push/checkout/etc with no issues.

Repos are all hosted on bitbucket.org.

It's always two login/authentication prompts, one after the other, regardless of how many repo tabs I have open.
fields.summary: Approx every 20 mins, get two prompts to login.

fields.description: Some times SourceTree get all available memory.  It cause swap and entire system became unresponsive.
fields.summary: High memory consumption

fields.description:
Current situation:

I have a list of .gits on a server.

I have a number of bookmarks, ordered into folders.

I collaborate on these projects with others.

 

The goal:

We would like to be able to use GIT to maintain these bookmarks, and automatically create new bookmarks when someone pulls the latest bookmarks I included.

This would serve as an easy way to collaborate with others and to restore on new installation.

One would only have to configure the bookmark GIT and pull.

 

My findings so far:

I've tried to get this to work with the existing SourceTree, but I am running into the following issues:

1)

Bookmarks.xml (in the user's localAppData) stores the bookmark information, but the URL is only stored in each separate local .git config file.

Therefore, it is not sufficient to only include the bookmarks.xml file.

To resolve this, the URL for the bookmarks would need to be stored in the bookmarks.xml

2)

The base folder (tools -> options -> repo settings -> project folder) would have to be a variable, so it takes it from the configuration.

3)

When a new bookmark is pulled, the folder and local .git would need to be created, similar to when a new bookmark is manually created.

 

Please let me know what you think! I think it would be a good new feature, especially when many GITs are in play with multiple collaborators.
fields.summary: Use GIT to control list of Bookmarks

fields.description:
If I have Sourcetree open, and I try to open Sourcetree _Beta_, the splash screen appears, then it closes and the focus switches to Sourcetree. Likewise, if I have Sourcetree _Beta_ open and I open Sourcetree, the splash screen opens, closes and the focus switches back to Sourcetree Beta.

I _thought_ that prior to Sourcetree Beta v3 I could run both versions simultaneously. I seem to remember doing this at some point in the past, but I haven't confirmed this as that would require me to uninstall the v3 beta and install the latest v2 beta.

It would be nice if this was possible because sometimes I see some behavior in the Beta and want to check if it also happened in the public release. To do that, I have to close Sourcetree Beta, open Sourcetree, check the behavior, then close it and re-open Sourcetree Beta. And sometimes I have to do this repeatedly to try different things.
fields.summary: Cannot open Sourcetree and Sourcetree Beta at the same time
